University of Michigan MS cline.  The docs have been phenomenal.  His first neuro was just O.K, and at Mayo Clinic, the doc was cold as ice, totally disinterested and almost heartless, although obviously intelligent and experience.  My son's wife constantly encourages him, sypathizes with him, but won't let him feel sorry for himself or bring her down.  She keeps him going.  But, the older kids are starting to notice the difference in my son, and have expressed fear that they too could get MS.  The dynamics are challenging, and anybody who blithely says "oh, just be positive"  hasn't a clue.  MS is a minute-to-minute struggle and takes great courage and fortitude to survive.  I have checked out many of your suggestions and my son's wife is also on the hunt for any potential help.I just read "What's Killing You and What To Do About it!" by Dr. Donald Monus and David Hamilton.  Monus claims to have cured an MS patient.  He is in Largo, Florida and his number is 727-585-2879.  No website.  But, you can be I will pass this info to my son.You have your hands full and I can only imagine the frustration and pain in your life.  But, continued hope and fierce intention to survive MS is a positive weapon in this fight.

U OF M IS A FANTASTIC CLINIC,I HAVN'T BEEN THERE FOR MY MS,BUT I HAVE HAD MY SON THERE FOR JUVENILE DIABETES AND MY DAUGHTER WAS RETRAINED BY A PROFESSOR FOR DYSLEXIA.I WAS THERE AND SEEN A NEUROSURGEON WHEN I LIVED IN MICHIGAN.WISH YOUR SON THE BEST OF LUCK AND PRAYERS TO ALL OF YA.THIS DISEASE DOES TAKE A TOLL ON EVERYONE,BUT ESPECIALLY OUR CHILDREN.I HAVE 4.T-LYNN

question: Hello.  thanks so much for posting your son's story.  My husband has had progressive leg weakness since 2004 and can no longer run, jump, swim, and has leg pain and spasms.  he has 16 T2 hyperintense lesions and whole brain atrophy, but no diagnosis.I would highly recommend reading "Climbing Higher" and "Living Well" by Montel Williams.  he talks about his experiences with MS.  he has his own foundation which contribute 100 percent of his donations to medical research for MS.  The Center Without Walls also spends alot of money on research for MS.  The MS society only spends about 20 cents per dollar contributed to research.I would also recommend the book "Up the Creek With A Paddle" about LDN.  You might want the information in the future.  Does your son have hyper reflexes on a neuro exam??We have six children and to tell you the truth, the emotional toll this whole disease has been taking on my husband is horrible.  It is destroying us and our family as the neuros continue to enjoy their lives.  I am so frustrated I could scream.I would also recommend "Lean On Me" and also go to the website for the "Rocky Mountain MS Center".  They embrace conventional and alternative medicine treatments for MS.  They seem very advanced and open to new ideas.  I like their website alot and they seem like a great place for people with MS.Can you please tell me what U of M stands for??Thank you again.  I appreciate your post.Elaine
